ygData.subject: Re: "Survive and Reproduce" as an Objective
ygData.msgSnippet: Colin, I agree with most of what you ve said, and will reply inline. However, if we are still debating whether biological fitness is an objective as typically

From: "joel278" <lehman.154@...>
Subject: Re: "Survive and Reproduce" as an Objective
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=130984297; y=ruVPz5OfVdFr14ByZEXpXUFTd73UoRySpu991SMMfaceT6MtqnXs
X-Yahoo-Profile: joel278

Colin,

I agree with most of what you've said, and will reply inline. Howev=
er, if we are still debating whether biological fitness is an objective as =
typically considered within EC,  I feel like the central argument I propose=
d wasn't addressed: The optimal replicator, in terms of fitness, is likely =
some super-efficient bacteria. If biological fitness is the objective, then=
 this super-bacteria is the global optima, this is what evolution should *s=
top* after it finds (as you propose in pole-balancing) -- anything else is =
worse, regardless of what strategy or resources it utilizes. 

Perhaps our =
discussion about objectives is merely semantic at this point. It is also in=
teresting to consider whether environmental complexity, like Earth's richne=
ss, is a requirement for creating an open-ended complexifying evolutionary =
system.

> The natural world has many different resources available, some a=
re
> trivially utilised like molecules or bits of food floating in the
> oc=
ean, others though are not immediately available to simple
> strategies (e.=
g. anything you need senses and motility to get at). The
> number and range=
 of types of resources is vast and ergo so to is the
> range of strategy co=
mplexity required to access them. The tendency
> towards complexity then is=
 not an innate quality of the evolutionary
> process, rather it's a reflect=
ion of the complexity of the natural
> world.
>

I think it is a leap to go=
 from the fact that different resources in natural evolution require differ=
ent complexities to exploit, to the more general claim that evolution's dri=
ve in some lineages to complexity is a reflection of the natural world's co=
mplexity. 

More important than Earth's complexity is the complexity of exi=
sting organisms; that is, new animals create new niches based upon existing=
 animals. Grass leads to herbivores etc. 

So in that sense, some of the co=
mplexity (probably what most people would agree is the most interesting com=
plexity, i.e. complex animals) is not innate in the system but is bootstrap=
ped from within the evolutionary algorithm (although admittedly dependent o=
n what is possible within Earth). 

Whether an endless supply of niches can=
 exist only in very complex domains (like Earth) is an interesting question=
. I would doubt it, and guess that our want to attribute evolution's majest=
y to Earth's unique complexity is because we don't yet understand the under=
lying (perhaps even simple) abstraction that allows natural evolution such =
creative power. For example, even a simple game like chess (few rules) disp=
lays a remarkable depth. What a self-bootstrapping niche-space within chess=
 would require, I don't know; but I wouldn't immediately discount that it c=
ould exist.

> >  Whatever can reproduce does;
> > different niches, even i=
f they are suboptimal when compared to other niches, still
> > accumulate.
=
> 
> OK so potentially I haven't gone into detail on this aspect. The
> dif=
ferent niches are often (but not always) spacially distinct, so
> e.g. a fi=
sh with legs moves on to land and has this whole new resource
> available. =
It not longer has to compete with sharks, etc, so yes it
> only has to be c=
ompetetive in that niche, which initially was very
> easy once you figured =
out how to grow legs and breath air. Each newly
> complex strategy potentia=
lly put the critter in question into virgin
> territory - an easy life but =
one that was only made possible by a new
> and more complex strategy.
> 

I=
 agree that competition is often localized within and between certain niche=
s, Ken and I have a publication at GECCO this year related to that idea. Bu=
t I think the larger point is that within these niches, a complex strategy =
is being discovered to do something that could ultimately be accomplished i=
n a much simpler way; i.e. if the goal is reproduction, you can do it bette=
r by being a bacteria. 

Natural evolution ultimately is a process that fin=
ds many ways to do the same thing -- reproduce. So in some sense, the compl=
exity of human beings is like that of a rube-goldberg machine: exceedingly =
complex, but ultimately the output (a fertilized egg cell) is the same as t=
hat of a bacteria (one cell). While humans are certainly well-adapted to ou=
r particular niche, the complexity is unwarranted for the task. I think a s=
imilar example in EC would be discovering a pole balancer that juggled pole=
s while doing wheelies and bouncing. While incredibly cool, the level of co=
mplexity is unbalanced with respect to the ultimate product (keeping the po=
les balanced). 

> No we would never find human beings in that domain, and =
nor should we
> expect to. The essential quality of my above argument is th=
at each
> complexification allowed colonisation of a new space that couldn'=
t be
> reached with simpler strategies. If there is a simple strategy for
>=
 pole balancing then we have found a global optimum and there is
> nowhere =
in teh fitness landscape that leads on from there. It's a dead
> end. The f=
itness space is lacking sufficient complexity to evolve
> anything more com=
plex than the domain requires.
> 
> Note that this isn't necessarily an arg=
ument against novelty search, I
> suspect that it still stands as a compete=
tive search strategy for
> certian classes of domain with the computational=
 resource restrictions
> we have.
> 

I think this may be where we most dis=
agree; it seems true that somewhere within the infinite space of NEAT/Hyper=
NEAT encoding schemes, that some sort of sophisticated brain exists (obviou=
sly, finding or reaching it is exceedingly difficult). If this is the case,=
 then couldn't this brain also potentially evolve in any domain, despite it=
s simplicity? Of course, such intelligence may be completely unnecessary; a=
s is human-level intelligence to reproduction. 

For example, a maze-naviga=
ting robot traversing a 2d-maze could learn how to navigate the maze by mak=
ing turns and motions based on deriving new digits of Pi through some spect=
acular recurrence. The question is if there is a reward scheme that could s=
omehow lead to this (or equally complex) behavior through some process wher=
e various inefficient yet interesting navigators were generated, or if such=
 a reward scheme is impossible.

My argument is that there are simple ways =
to reproduce, just as there are simple ways to navigate mazes. I think we b=
oth agree that reaching new niches (utilizing new resources) is only possib=
le because of exploring existing ways of life (existing utilization of reso=
urces). However, our key disagreement is whether the complexity that arises=
 in natural evolution really is in some sense rube-goldbergian in the same =
way as a Pi-deriving maze navigator.

Joel
